channel.title: Nature
channel.description: Nature is the foremost international weekly scientific journal in the world and is the flagship journal for Nature Portfolio. It publishes the finest peer-reviewed research in all fields of science and technology on the basis of its originality, importance, interdisciplinary interest, timeliness, accessibility, elegance and surprising conclusions. Nature publishes landmark papers, award winning news, leading comment and expert opinion on important, topical scientific news and events that enable readers to share the latest discoveries in science and evolve the discussion amongst the global scientific community.
channel.dc:rights: © 2023 Macmillan Publishers Limited, part of Springer Nature. All rights reserved.
channel.prism:copyright: © 2023 Macmillan Publishers Limited, part of Springer Nature. All rights reserved.

item.title: I ski for miles in the wilderness to measure dust atop snow
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 04 September 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02737-9

Snow hydrologist McKenzie Skiles takes to her skis in rural parts of the United States each spring to track dust’s impact on water resources.
item.dc:title: I ski for miles in the wilderness to measure dust atop snow
item.dc:creator: Virginia Gewin

item.title: India’s first Sun mission will investigate the origins of space weather
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 04 September 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02811-2

The Aditya-L1 million will join other spacecraft from Europe and the United States in an attempt to understand our stormy star.
item.dc:title: India’s first Sun mission will investigate the origins of space weather
item.dc:creator: T.V. Padma

item.title: Dust: how the pursuit of power and profit has turned the world to powder
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 04 September 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02734-y

From atmospheric nuclear testing to the US Dust Bowl, human activities have left a toxic legacy of particulate pollution — and the unseen fallout continues to this day.
item.dc:title: Dust: how the pursuit of power and profit has turned the world to powder
item.dc:creator: Alexandra Witze

item.title: Author Correction: Women are credited less in science than men
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 01 September 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06571-x

Author Correction: Women are credited less in science than men
item.dc:title: Author Correction: Women are credited less in science than men
item.dc:creator: Matthew B. Ross
Britta M. Glennon
Raviv Murciano-Goroff
Enrico G. Berkes
Bruce A. Weinberg
Julia I. Lane

item.title: Genomes reveal yellow fever’s deadly route through Brazil
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 01 September 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02716-0

New RNA sequences show the path that the virus travelled from the Amazon to the densely populated south.
item.dc:title: Genomes reveal yellow fever’s deadly route through Brazil

item.title: A funding adviser’s guide to writing a great grant application
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 01 September 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02756-6

Mireille Consalvey draws on years of experience to present a 13-step checklist for success.
item.dc:title: A funding adviser’s guide to writing a great grant application
item.dc:creator: Mireille Consalvey

item.title: Action spectroscopy of a single gas molecule
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 01 September 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02393-z

Spectroscopy is widely used to characterize samples. Here, spectroscopy of a single molecule of the tropylium cation (C7H7+) presents a new approach to analysis, particularly for rare or reactive molecular ions that are probably important in interstellar chemistry.
item.dc:title: Action spectroscopy of a single gas molecule

item.title: Daily briefing: Our distant ancestors nearly went extinct 900,000 years ago
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 01 September 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02815-y

An unknown human-like species was reduced to just 1,280 breeding individuals, creating a genetic bottleneck that is still detectable in the DNA of modern-day humans. Plus, research bases have polluted the Antarctic and how to do the hard work of greening your lab.
item.dc:title: Daily briefing: Our distant ancestors nearly went extinct 900,000 years ago
item.dc:creator: Flora Graham

item.title: Antarctic research stations have polluted a pristine wilderness
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 01 September 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02740-0

Historical bad practices have left a legacy of pollution, but efforts are under way to chart a better future.
item.dc:title: Antarctic research stations have polluted a pristine wilderness
item.dc:creator: Gemma Conroy

item.title: How would room-temperature superconductors change science?
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 01 September 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02681-8

The prized materials could be transformative for research — but only if they have other essential qualities.
item.dc:title: How would room-temperature superconductors change science?
item.dc:creator: Davide Castelvecchi

item.title: See a star being born and more — August’s best science images
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 01 September 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02700-8

The month’s sharpest science shots, selected by Nature’s photo team.
item.dc:title: See a star being born and more — August’s best science images
item.dc:creator: Emma Stoye

item.title: Medical-evidence giant Cochrane battles funding cuts and closures
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 01 September 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02741-z

The group that helped to revolutionize medical practice has lost key funding and is reorganizing — moves that concern some researchers.
item.dc:title: Medical-evidence giant Cochrane battles funding cuts and closures
item.dc:creator: Helen Pearson

item.title: Melaku Worede, crop genetics leader (1936–2023)
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 31 August 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02735-x

Plant geneticist who pioneered seed conservation for famine resilience and farmer livelihoods.
item.dc:title: Melaku Worede, crop genetics leader (1936–2023)
item.dc:creator: Regassa Feyissa
Toby Hodgkin

item.title: AI predicts chemicals’ smells from their structures
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 31 August 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02714-2

Neural network can provide descriptions, such as ‘grassy’, for a wide variety of molecules, including some that don’t exist in nature.
item.dc:title: AI predicts chemicals’ smells from their structures
item.dc:creator: Sara Reardon

item.title: A funder's guide to tackling setbacks and winning grants
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 31 August 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02754-8

European Research Council president Maria Leptin speaks about her career experience and how to handle disappointment in science.
item.dc:title: A funder's guide to tackling setbacks and winning grants
item.dc:creator: Julie Gould
Jack Leeming

item.title: Daily briefing: First detection of oxygen-28 defies expectations
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 31 August 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02761-9

Scientists are surprised by the initial observations of the 28O nucleus. Plus, people with type 1 diabetes are building their own treatment tech, and a battle for the soul of beekeeping.
item.dc:title: Daily briefing: First detection of oxygen-28 defies expectations
item.dc:creator: Flora Graham

item.title: Human ancestors nearly went extinct 900,000 years ago
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 31 August 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02712-4

A new technique analysing modern genetic data suggests that pre-humans survived in a group of only 1,280 individuals.
item.dc:title: Human ancestors nearly went extinct 900,000 years ago
item.dc:creator: Anna Ikarashi

item.title: How we set our lab on an environmentally sustainable path
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 31 August 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02736-w

Leading a drive to lower your lab’s carbon footprint alongside your PhD research is tough. Start by celebrating small successes, says Caroline Giuglaris.
item.dc:title: How we set our lab on an environmentally sustainable path
item.dc:creator: Caroline Giuglaris

item.title: Strike at outbreak-alert service ProMED to end — but tensions remain
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 31 August 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02750-y

Most of the striking ProMED staff members are prepared to return to work, although many still have concerns.
item.dc:title: Strike at outbreak-alert service ProMED to end — but tensions remain
item.dc:creator: Max Kozlov

item.title: Biotechnologist’s long-life bananas unite business and social solutions
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 31 August 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02755-7

George William Byarugaba Bazirake brings academic values to his company.
item.dc:title: Biotechnologist’s long-life bananas unite business and social solutions
item.dc:creator: Christopher Bendana

item.title: Publisher Correction: Population-based heteropolymer design to mimic protein mixtures
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 30 August 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06554-y

Publisher Correction: Population-based heteropolymer design to mimic protein mixtures
item.dc:title: Publisher Correction: Population-based heteropolymer design to mimic protein mixtures

Publisher Correction: Scientific discovery in the age of artificial intelligence
item.dc:title: Publisher Correction: Scientific discovery in the age of artificial intelligence

item.title: AI finally beats humans at a real-life sport — drone racing
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 30 August 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02719-x

The new system combines simulation with onboard sensing and computation.
item.dc:title: AI finally beats humans at a real-life sport — drone racing
item.dc:creator: Dan Fox

item.title: Physicists finally observe strange isotope Oxygen 28 – raising fundamental questions
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 30 August 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02731-1

The long-sought finding challenges scientists' understanding of the strong nuclear force, and the AI that can beat human champions at drone racing.
item.dc:title: Physicists finally observe strange isotope Oxygen 28 – raising fundamental questions
item.dc:creator: Dan Fox
Nick Petrić Howe

item.title: A chemical cage holds promise for a better hydrogen-powered fuel cell
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 30 August 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02678-3

Membrane material improves power generation from hydrogen gas — and catalyses the gas’s production from water.
item.dc:title: A chemical cage holds promise for a better hydrogen-powered fuel cell

item.title: Which graduate students gain patents? Gender holds an answer
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 30 August 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02680-9

PhD students with supervisors who are prolific inventors have an edge, as do male students.
item.dc:title: Which graduate students gain patents? Gender holds an answer

item.title: Climate warming increases extreme daily wildfire growth risk in California
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 30 August 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06444-3

Quantification of climate warming in California using machine learning shows increased daily wildfire growth risk by 25%, with an expected increase of 59% and 172% in 2100, for low- and very-high-emissions scenarios, respectively.
item.dc:title: Climate warming increases extreme daily wildfire growth risk in California
item.dc:creator: Patrick T. Brown
Holt Hanley
Ankur Mahesh
Colorado Reed
Scott J. Strenfel
Steven J. Davis
Adam K. Kochanski
Craig B. Clements

item.title: Epitope editing enables targeted immunotherapy of acute myeloid leukaemia
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 30 August 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06496-5

Epitope engineering of donor haematopoietic stem/progenitor cells endows haematopoietic lineages with selective resistance to CAR T cells or monoclonal antibodies, without affecting protein function or regulation, enabling the targeting of genes that are essential for leukaemia survival and reducing the risk of tumour immune escape.
item.dc:title: Epitope editing enables targeted immunotherapy of acute myeloid leukaemia
item.dc:creator: Gabriele Casirati
Andrea Cosentino

item.title: Marine heatwaves are not a dominant driver of change in demersal fishes
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 30 August 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06449-y

Of 248 marine heatwaves between 1993 and 2019 in North American and European seas, the effects on fish biomass were often minimal, and the heatwaves were not consistently associated with tropicalization or deborealization.
item.dc:title: Marine heatwaves are not a dominant driver of change in demersal fishes
item.dc:creator: Alexa L. Fredston
William W. L. Cheung

Malin L. Pinsky

item.title: First observation of <sup>28</sup>O
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 30 August 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06352-6

Observation of 28O and 27O through their decay into 24O and four and three neutrons, respectively, is reported, with the 28O nucleus being of particular interest owing to proton and neutron magic numbers and its extremely asymmetric neutron-to-proton ratio.
item.dc:title: First observation of <sup>28</sup>O

item.title: A pentameric TRPV3 channel with a dilated pore
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 30 August 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06470-1

High-speed atomic force microscopy single-molecule imaging and cryo-EM analysis discover and reveal the structure of a TRPV3 pentamer, providing evidence for a non-canonical pentameric TRP-channel assembly, laying the foundation for new directions in TRP channel research.
item.dc:title: A pentameric TRPV3 channel with a dilated pore
item.dc:creator: Shifra Lansky
John Michael Betancourt
Jingying Zhang
Yining Jiang
Elizabeth D. Kim
Navid Paknejad
Crina M. Nimigean
Peng Yuan
Simon Scheuring

item.title: A super-massive Neptune-sized planet
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 30 August 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06499-2

Observations of the super-massive Neptune-sized transiting planet TOI-1853 b show a mass almost twice that of any other Neptune-sized planet known so far and a bulk density implying that heavy elements dominate its mass.
item.dc:title: A super-massive Neptune-sized planet

item.title: Identifying attacks in the Russia–Ukraine conflict using seismic array data
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 30 August 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06416-7

Analysis of seismic waves caused by explosions in northern Ukraine recorded by a local network in 2022 demonstrated the ability to automatically identify individual attacks during the Russia–Ukraine conflict in close to real time.
item.dc:title: Identifying attacks in the Russia–Ukraine conflict using seismic array data
item.dc:creator: Ben D. E. Dando
Bettina P. Goertz-Allmann
Quentin Brissaud
Andreas Köhler
Johannes Schweitzer
Tormod Kværna
Alexander Liashchuk

item.title: CRISPR screens decode cancer cell pathways that trigger γδ T cell detection
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 30 August 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06482-x

A combination of genome-wide CRISPR screens in target cancer cells identifies pathways that regulate γδ T cell killing and BTN3A cell surface expression.
item.dc:title: CRISPR screens decode cancer cell pathways that trigger γδ T cell detection
item.dc:creator: Murad R. Mamedov
Shane Vedova

item.title: Structure evolution at the gate-tunable suspended graphene–water interface
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 30 August 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06374-0

Using centimetre-sized substrate-free monolayer graphene suspended on aqueous electrolyte surface, the structural evolution versus gate voltage at the graphene–water interface is shown, demonstrating minimal influence of extrinsic factors.
item.dc:title: Structure evolution at the gate-tunable suspended graphene–water interface
item.dc:creator: Ying Xu
You-Bo Ma
Feng Gu
Shan-Shan Yang
Chuan-Shan Tian

item.title: Neutralization, effector function and immune imprinting of Omicron variants
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 30 August 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06487-6

Convergent mutations in hot spots of the spike proteins of currently circulating SARS-CoV-2 Omicron variants increase the binding affinity for the host receptor and promote more efficient fusion with host cell membranes.
item.dc:title: Neutralization, effector function and immune imprinting of Omicron variants

item.title: An orexigenic subnetwork within the human hippocampus
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 30 August 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06459-w

An appetite-regulating subnetwork in humans involving the lateral hypothalamus and the dorsolateral hippocampus is implicated in obesity and related eating disorders.
item.dc:title: An orexigenic subnetwork within the human hippocampus
item.dc:creator: Daniel A. N. Barbosa

item.title: Champion-level drone racing using deep reinforcement learning
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 30 August 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06419-4

An autonomous system is described that combines deep reinforcement learning with onboard sensors collecting data from the physical world, enabling it to fly faster than human world champion drone pilots around a race track.
item.dc:title: Champion-level drone racing using deep reinforcement learning
item.dc:creator: Elia Kaufmann
Leonard Bauersfeld
Antonio Loquercio
Matthias Müller
Vladlen Koltun
Davide Scaramuzza

item.title: Gut microbial carbohydrate metabolism contributes to insulin resistance
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 30 August 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06466-x

Faecal carbohydrates, particularly host-accessible monosaccharides, are increased in individuals with insulin resistance and are associated with microbial carbohydrate metabolisms and host inflammatory cytokines.
item.dc:title: Gut microbial carbohydrate metabolism contributes to insulin resistance
item.dc:creator: Tadashi Takeuchi
Tetsuya Kubota

Hiroshi Ohno

item.title: Hippocampal representation during collective spatial behaviour in bats
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 30 August 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06478-7

In bats engaged in spontaneous collective spatial behaviour, a robust spatial structure emerges at the group level whereby behaviour is anchored to specific locations, movement patterns and individual social preferences, and many hippocampal neurons are tuned to key features of group dynamics.
item.dc:title: Hippocampal representation during collective spatial behaviour in bats
item.dc:creator: Angelo Forli
Michael M. Yartsev

item.title: Identification of an alternative triglyceride biosynthesis pathway
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 30 August 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06497-4

Triacylglycerols are an energy source produced in humans by DGAT1 and DGAT2, but disrupting these enzymes reveals a noncanonical pathway involving the protein DIESL (formerly TMEM68) and its regulator TMX1, which is important during lipid scarcity.
item.dc:title: Identification of an alternative triglyceride biosynthesis pathway
item.dc:creator: Gian-Luca McLelland

item.title: Scalable spin squeezing in a dipolar Rydberg atom array
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 30 August 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06414-9

In the dipolar XY model, quench dynamics from a polarized initial state lead to spin squeezing that improves with increasing system size, and two refinements show further enhanced squeezing and extended lifetime of the squeezed state by freezing its dynamics.
item.dc:title: Scalable spin squeezing in a dipolar Rydberg atom array

Antoine Browaeys

item.title: Realizing spin squeezing with Rydberg interactions in an optical clock
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 30 August 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06360-6

Spin squeezing in an optical atomic clock based on arrays of neutral atoms is used to realize measurement performance below the standard quantum limit.
item.dc:title: Realizing spin squeezing with Rydberg interactions in an optical clock
item.dc:creator: William J. Eckner
Nelson Darkwah Oppong
Alec Cao
Aaron W. Young
William R. Milner
John M. Robinson
Jun Ye
Adam M. Kaufman

item.title: Metabolic programs of T cell tissue residency empower tumour immunity
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 30 August 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06483-w

A study describes the metabolic adaptations supporting differentiation, survival and function of tissue-resident memory CD8+ T cells and how to leverage them to enhance immunity against pathogens and tumours.
item.dc:title: Metabolic programs of T cell tissue residency empower tumour immunity
item.dc:creator: Miguel Reina-Campos
Maximilian Heeg
Kelly Kennewick
Ian T. Mathews

item.title: High-resolution landscape of an antibiotic binding site
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 30 August 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06495-6

A collection of RNA polymerase mutants spanning all possible substitutions of the rifampicin binding site is generated and characterized, increasing our understanding of antibiotic mechanisms and bacterial physiology.
item.dc:title: High-resolution landscape of an antibiotic binding site
item.dc:creator: Kevin B. Yang
Maria Cameranesi
Manjunath Gowder
Criseyda Martinez
Yosef Shamovsky
Vitaliy Epshtein

Aviram Rasouly
Evgeny Nudler

item.title: Widespread retreat of coastal habitat is likely at warming levels above 1.5 °C
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 30 August 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06448-z

Without mitigation, relative sea-level rises under current climate change projections will exceed the capacity of coastal habitats such as mangroves and tidal marshes to adjust, leading to instability and profound changes to coastal ecosystems.
item.dc:title: Widespread retreat of coastal habitat is likely at warming levels above 1.5 °C
item.dc:creator: Neil Saintilan
Benjamin Horton
Torbjörn E. Törnqvist
Erica L. Ashe
Nicole S. Khan
Mark Schuerch
Chris Perry

Catherine E. Lovelock
Madeline M. Goddard
Lindsay B. Hutley
Katya Kovalenko
Laura Feher
Glenn Guntenspergen

item.title: Anthropogenic fingerprints in daily precipitation revealed by deep learning
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 30 August 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06474-x

Deep learning using a convolutional neural network trained with daily precipitation fields and annual global mean surface air temperature data demonstrates that anthropogenically induced climate change has a detectable effect on daily hydrological fluctuations.
item.dc:title: Anthropogenic fingerprints in daily precipitation revealed by deep learning
item.dc:creator: Yoo-Geun Ham
Jeong-Hwan Kim
Seung-Ki Min
Daehyun Kim
Tim Li
Axel Timmermann
Malte F. Stuecker

item.title: A microscale soft ionic power source modulates neuronal network activity
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 30 August 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06295-y

A study describes the development of a miniaturized hydrogel-based soft power source capable of modulating the activity of networks of neuronal cells without the need for metal electrodes.
item.dc:title: A microscale soft ionic power source modulates neuronal network activity
item.dc:creator: Yujia Zhang
Jorin Riexinger
Xingyun Yang
Ellina Mikhailova
Yongcheng Jin
Linna Zhou
Hagan Bayley

item.title: Indistinguishable telecom band photons from a single Er ion in the solid state
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 30 August 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06281-4

Er3+ is implanted into CaWO4, a material with non-polar site symmetry free of background rare earth ions, to realize reduced optical spectral diffusion in nanophotonic devices, representing a step towards making telecom band quantum repeater networks with single ions.
item.dc:title: Indistinguishable telecom band photons from a single Er ion in the solid state
item.dc:creator: Salim Ourari
Łukasz Dusanowski
Sebastian P. Horvath
Mehmet T. Uysal

Mouktik Raha

Robert J. Cava
Nathalie P. de Leon
Jeff D. Thompson

item.title: LTP induction by structural rather than enzymatic functions of CaMKII
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 30 August 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06465-y

Several independent lines of evidence demonstrated long-term potentiation induction by a structural function of calmodulin-dependent protein kinase II rather than by its enzymatic activity.
item.dc:title: LTP induction by structural rather than enzymatic functions of CaMKII
item.dc:creator: Jonathan E. Tullis
Matthew E. Larsen
Nicole L. Rumian
Ronald K. Freund
Emma E. Boxer

Jason Aoto
Mark L. Dell’Acqua
K. Ulrich Bayer

item.title: Quantum-enhanced sensing on optical transitions through finite-range interactions
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 30 August 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06472-z

A method is described for the generation of large-scale entanglement that can be used for quantum-enhanced sensing even when systems are limited to short-range interactions in experiments with up to 51 trapped ions.
item.dc:title: Quantum-enhanced sensing on optical transitions through finite-range interactions
item.dc:creator: Johannes Franke
Sean R. Muleady
Raphael Kaubruegger
Florian Kranzl
Rainer Blatt
Ana Maria Rey
Manoj K. Joshi
Christian F. Roos

item.title: Maui fires could taint the island’s waters — scientists are investigating
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 30 August 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02707-1

Researchers in Hawaii are studying the deadly blazes’ effects on drinking-water quality and how they might affect local marine ecosystems.
item.dc:title: Maui fires could taint the island’s waters — scientists are investigating
item.dc:creator: Jeff Tollefson

item.title: A DIY ‘bionic pancreas’ is changing diabetes care — what's next?
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 30 August 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02648-9

A community of people with type 1 diabetes got a self-built device approved. What can they offer that big companies can’t?
item.dc:title: A DIY ‘bionic pancreas’ is changing diabetes care — what's next?
item.dc:creator: Liam Drew

item.title: Rethinking the effect of marine heatwaves on fish
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 30 August 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02594-6

Marine heatwaves are on the rise. A surprising result from the analysis of data for fish populations in Europe and North America could change ways of thinking about the ecological consequences of such events.
item.dc:title: Rethinking the effect of marine heatwaves on fish
item.dc:creator: Mark R. Payne

item.title: A step closer to repeaters for quantum networks
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 30 August 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02283-4

Loss of photons over long-distance connections limits the development of quantum networks, necessitating the use of quantum ‘repeater’ systems to boost signals between network nodes. Erbium ions incorporated into calcium tungstate crystals have been found to emit photons in the telecommunications frequency band that are indistinguishable from each other, and thus show promise for use in such repeaters.
item.dc:title: A step closer to repeaters for quantum networks

item.title: Previously unknown pathway for lipid biosynthesis discovered
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 30 August 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02502-y

The pathway used by mammalian cells to make triglyceride lipids when supplies of fat molecules are high has long been known. A route that works when fat supplies are low has now been discovered.
item.dc:title: Previously unknown pathway for lipid biosynthesis discovered
item.dc:creator: Jean E. Schaffer

item.title: University mourns nanoscientist killed on UNC campus
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 30 August 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02724-0

Zijie Yan led a laboratory at the University of North Carolina that studied light–matter interactions on the nanometre scale.
item.dc:title: University mourns nanoscientist killed on UNC campus
item.dc:creator: Mariana Lenharo

item.title: Gifts from the cyborg battlefront
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 30 August 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02660-z

Straight from the heart.
item.dc:title: Gifts from the cyborg battlefront
item.dc:creator: Rachael K. Jones

item.title: Dynamic ion channel defies dogma
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 30 August 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02486-9

It is well established that proteins in the TRP family of ion channels assemble from four subunits. But do they always do this? A five-subunit structure has now been observed, and might be involved in channel regulation.
item.dc:title: Dynamic ion channel defies dogma
item.dc:creator: Ute A. Hellmich

item.title: COVID infection risk rises the longer you are exposed — even for vaccinated people
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 30 August 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02715-1

Rigorous evidence shows that significant contact with a person with SARS-CoV-2 is more likely to lead to transmission than a short encounter.
item.dc:title: COVID infection risk rises the longer you are exposed — even for vaccinated people
item.dc:creator: Anil Oza

item.title: A drowned future for coastal ecosystems
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 30 August 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02595-5

Tidal marshes, mangroves and coral reefs support the livelihoods of millions of people. Most of these ecosystems will be vulnerable to submergence owing to rapid sea-level rise if global warming exceeds 2 °C above pre-industrial levels.
item.dc:title: A drowned future for coastal ecosystems
item.dc:creator: Qiang He

item.title: Controversial dwarfism drugs spur growth — but do they improve health?
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 30 August 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02647-w

Emerging treatments for achondroplasia pose difficult choices for parents. Proponents say they are changing lives. Others fear they will feed stigma and erase identity.
item.dc:title: Controversial dwarfism drugs spur growth — but do they improve health?
item.dc:creator: Cassandra Willyard

item.title: Peering into bats’ brains as the animals fly and feed together
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 30 August 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02451-6

Many animals, including humans, live together and move in coordination with others, but little is known about how neurons represent or govern such complex behaviours. By studying free-flying bats, we found that neural activity in a region of the brain called the hippocampus contains a rich representation of the spatial and social environment that could support collective behaviour.
item.dc:title: Peering into bats’ brains as the animals fly and feed together

item.title: Rare oxygen isotope detected at last — and it defies expectations
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 30 August 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02713-3

Oxygen-28 might prompt physicists to revamp theories of how atomic nuclei are structured.
item.dc:title: Rare oxygen isotope detected at last — and it defies expectations
item.dc:creator: Katherine Bourzac

item.title: Monitoring an active war zone in Ukraine using seismic data
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 30 August 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02454-3

Seismic data have been used to continuously identify individual military explosions in Ukraine. Such conflict monitoring provides unprecedented details of these attacks and an objective data source that is essential for accurate war reporting and for identifying potential breaches of international law.
item.dc:title: Monitoring an active war zone in Ukraine using seismic data

item.title: Daily briefing: Scientist shot at US university, PhD student arrested
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 30 August 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02744-w

‘Beloved colleague, mentor and friend’ killed in science building at the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill. Plus, Emperor penguins flee melting ice and how to fix carbon offsets.
item.dc:title: Daily briefing: Scientist shot at US university, PhD student arrested
item.dc:creator: Flora Graham

item.title: Heaviest oxygen isotope is found to be unbound
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 30 August 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02485-w

The isotope oxygen-28 is expected to be ‘doubly magic’, with strongly bound neutrons and protons in its nucleus. Experiments now reveal that it exists in an unbound state — casting doubt on its magic status.
item.dc:title: Heaviest oxygen isotope is found to be unbound
item.dc:creator: Rituparna Kanungo

item.title: A platform for exploring microscopic processes at electrode–electrolyte interfaces
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 30 August 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02704-4

A centimetre-sized monolayer of the material graphene has been suspended on the surface of an aqueous electrolyte to investigate the intrinsic properties of the graphene–electrolyte interface. The results, based on optical spectroscopy, could aid the design and study of state-of-the-art electrochemical devices.
item.dc:title: A platform for exploring microscopic processes at electrode–electrolyte interfaces

item.title: Drone-racing champions outpaced by AI
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 30 August 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02506-8

An autonomous drone has competed against human drone-racing champions — and won. The victory can be attributed to savvy engineering and a type of artificial intelligence that learns mostly through trial and error.
item.dc:title: Drone-racing champions outpaced by AI
item.dc:creator: Guido C. H. E. de Croon

item.title: From the archive: colour constancy, and an atomic romance
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 29 August 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02652-z

Snippets from Nature’s past.
item.dc:title: From the archive: colour constancy, and an atomic romance

item.title: The DNA in a sea sponge’s pores shows what lives nearby
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 29 August 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02679-2

Fragments of DNA extracted from these aquatic animals record the diversity of their neighbours.
item.dc:title: The DNA in a sea sponge’s pores shows what lives nearby

item.title: Neurotechnology: we need new laws, not new rights
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 29 August 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02698-z

Neurotechnology: we need new laws, not new rights
item.dc:title: Neurotechnology: we need new laws, not new rights
item.dc:creator: Sjors Ligthart
Christoph Bublitz
Susie Alegre

item.title: Cleaning the air boosts forests’ cooling powers
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 29 August 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02677-4

Planting trees has a stronger effect on local temperature if air pollution is curbed.
item.dc:title: Cleaning the air boosts forests’ cooling powers

item.title: WHO: a global boost for evidence-based traditional medicine
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 29 August 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02699-y

WHO: a global boost for evidence-based traditional medicine
item.dc:title: WHO: a global boost for evidence-based traditional medicine
item.dc:creator: Bhushan Patwardhan
L. Susan Wieland
Shyama Kuruvilla

item.title: Shark culling at a World Heritage site
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 29 August 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02697-0

Shark culling at a World Heritage site
item.dc:title: Shark culling at a World Heritage site
item.dc:creator: Philippe Borsa
Martine Cornaille
Bertrand Richer de Forges
